Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Blake H. Barker is "Numerical Investigation of Problems in Stability, Including Numerical Analysis, Development of a Software Package, and Numerical Proof." The host institution for the fellowship is Brown University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Bjorn Sandstede.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Waves are ubiquitous in nature, manifesting in such diverse ways as roll waves on inclined surfaces (like a dam spillway), combustion fronts in detonations, and vegetation waves in arid landscapes, to name just a few. Modeling and understanding wave behavior well can be useful in science and engineering applications. A useful model should have solutions that capture the observed physical behavior. If waves are observed in nature, one would expect the corresponding solution to be stable, or at least metastable, in the mathematical model. Hence, determining stability properties of traveling waves plays an important role in both model validation and understanding physical phenomena. The Evans function is a particularly useful mathematical tool for determining the stability of traveling waves. However, generally the Evans function must be approximated numerically for the problems of interest. If these computations are done with rigorous and complete error tracking, then one may conclude with certainty that the wave is stable, or unstable, based on these computations. 

 

The PI made substantial progress developing algorithms and methods that can be used to rigorously verify the stability of traveling waves. In particular, we made solid strides in achieving the main goal of the grant proposal of developing a rigorous computer assisted proof method for computing the Evans function with completely rigorous error bounds. Using the methods developed, we proved stability of traveling waves in the one-dimensional isentropic Navier-Stokes equations with an adiabatic pressure law.  In addition, we studied stability of traveling waves in a variety of physical models to gain insight into natural phenomena including roll waves, source defects, and magnetohydrodynamics (MHD). Our study indicates a band of stable periodic waves in shallow water flow. We developed numerical methods allowing us to study stability of multi-dimensional planar waves in MHD. In addition, the PI co-mentored students in work that lead to the development of an algorithm for solving the Evans function as a boundary value problem. In completing these studies, the PI worked closely with collaborators from a variety of institutions. 

 

An important aspect of mathematical research is building up the next generation of math researchers and spreading the new mathematical concepts and techniques discovered. The PI co-mentored three students participating in a research experience for undergraduates which led to a publication. Two of these students continued on to graduate school at the University of Washington and the University of California Berkeley, and the third student was accepted into officer school. The PI mentored an additional 9 undergraduate students at his home institution, with ongoing mentoring expected to lead to several publications. Several of the students mentored come from under represented groups in math. The PI also co-organized several mini symposiums at conferences that brought together researchers from the computer assisted proof and stability of traveling waves communities to help disseminate the unique mathematical tools each group uses. The PI also chaired a panel discussion on computer assisted proof at a SIAM conference. The new numerical methods developed in this work are incorporated in STABLAB, a software package that the PI helps develop for studying the stability of traveling waves.
